Efficient decarbonylation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural over an Pd/Al2O3 catalyst: Preparation via electrostatic attraction between Pd(II) complex and anionic Al2O3 Qingwei Meng a b Chengwu Qiu a b Hongyan Zheng c Xianqing Li c Yulei Zhu a c ⁎ Yongwang Li a c a State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion Institute of Coal Chemistry Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan 030001 PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100039, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100039 PR China c Synfuels China Co. Ltd., Beijing 101407, PR China Synfuels China Co. Ltd. Beijing 101407 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author at: State Key Laboratory of Coal Conversion, Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, PR China. Graphical abstract Decarbonylation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) provides a potential way to utilize the abundant natural hexoses derived from cellulose or hemicellulose. Herein, we propose for the first time that a Pd/Al2O3 prepared based on an electrostatic attraction strategy can efficiently convert HMF into furfuryl alcohol (FOL). Ammonia solution with high pH value could realize the electrostatic attraction assumption in the interface of support and palladium complex, while diluted hydrochloric acid with low pH value could cause the instability of H+ ions on Al2O3 surface, leading to larger Pd nanoparticles (NPs) of the catalyst and lowering the decarbonylation activity. A structure-sensitive behavior was discussed that the intrinsic activity of catalyst rised with the decreased size of Pd NPs, which could be illustrated by that the smaller particles exposed more defective Pd sites, on which the decarbonylation adsorption mode of η2(C, O) was preferred. FOL yield of 95% was obtained through modulation of reaction conditions. Keywords Pd/Al2O3 Electrostatic attraction pH 5-hydroxymethylfurfural Decarbonylation 1 Introduction Noble catalysts, as widely known are expensive. How to improve the dispersion or to lower the loading of noble metal is the continued pursuit in catalysis research. Pd/Al2O3, as a commercially available catalyst, [1] has been widely used in the catalytic transformation, including hydrogenation [2–8] and hydrogenolysis [9] reactions, oxidation [10–13] and reduction [14–16] reactions, reforming [17] and isomerization [18] reactions, etc. The strong metal-support interaction and the synergistic effect of the metallic sites and the Lewis acid sites promise Pd/Al2O3 a good stability and superior catalytic performances. [17–19] Thus, preparing efficient Pd/Al2O3 catalyst is highly desirable but challenging. Generally, metallic nanoparticles (NPs) with small sizes exhibit high catalytic activity. [20–26] For example, anchoring Pd species onto the support through bifunctional ligands has been adopted to prepare highly dispersed Pd based catalysts. [27–29] However, the generally complicated preparation methods, such as vapor deposition, alcohol reduction or photodeposition method, restricted their application on a large scale. Incipient wetness impregnation is the most commonly used method to prepare supported noble metal catalysts, considering its safety, simpleness and low cost. [7,24,30–34] Therefore, it is of great significance to develop an effective impregnation method to promote dispersion of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst with small Pd NPs. Moreover, it would shed light on the preparation method of other noble metal catalysts. The impregnation process usually involves different adsorption interactions between active species and the support, which could be tuned by properly choosing the metal compound, the carrier or the pH of the solution. [35,36] The adsorption of palladium complexes on alumina may results from either electrostatic interaction or from simple physisorption. The adsorption strength is affected by the pH of the impregnation solution, as either the charges of the complex or the electric state of the support surface is pH dependent. Al2O3 obtains large amount of hydroxyl groups on the surface especially in the presence of water. [37] In contact with the active phase solution, the surface OH may undergo protonation (when the pH is below the isoelectric point (IEP) of the alumina) or deprotonation (when the pH>IEP of the support). [38] Thus, the support surface would be positively or negatively charged as shown in Scheme 1 . Furthermore, the palladium complex could also be negatively charged (for example in form of [PdCl4]2− or [PdCl3]− with high hydrochloric acid content) or positively charged (for example [Pd(NH3)4]2+ with ammonia water) depending on the pH of solution. [39] On the basis of this understanding, it is envisaged that a highly dispersed Pd/Al2O3 could be prepared through electrostatic attraction between surface-charged support and metallic ions at low pH or at high pH. However, usually Pd/Al2O3 catalysts are prepared by acidic impregnation solution of palladium salts and are restricted to poor dispersion. [40–42] It even has been reported that a highly dispersed Pd/Al2O3 catalyst with high activity was prepared at pH=10, while that prepared at pH=4 was poorly dispersed. [43] This is not consistent with the electrostatic attraction mechanism so well and no work has illustrated this contradiction. Furthermore, though the adsorption isotherm of Pd (II) on alumina at different pH has been studied long ago [44], the effect of pH on the dispersion of catalysts and further on their performances has not been investigated systematically. In this work, we envisage promoting dispersion of Pd/Al2O3 via metal-support electrostatic attraction by tuning the pH of impregnation solution and further shed light on the action mechanism of the pH. Recently, decarbonylation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF, one of the key platform chemical in the biomass utilization from cellulose) [45] to furfuryl alcohol (FOL) has attracted much attention (Scheme 2 ) [46]. Presently, homogeneous (Ir compounds) [47] and heterogeneous catalyst (Pd/SBA-15) [46] have been investigated on decarbonylation of HMF aiming at a high FOL yield. However, the homogenous catalyst is unrecoverable and the heterogeneous Pd/SBA-15 is necessarily in need of molecule sieves for unclear reasons presently. Pd/Al2O3 has been used for decarbonylation of HMF, but the catalytic activity is remained to be promoted. [30] Furthermore, it has been reported that, decarbonylation of another platform chemical-furfural is highly structure sensitive, exhibiting high decarbonylation activity on small metallic particles. [25] Therefore, it is expected to be favorable to perform HMF decarbonylation on Pd/Al2O3 catalyst with smaller Pd NPs. In this work, a wide scale of pH values (1–14) were investigated for preparation of Pd/Al2O3 catalyst. The surface charges of Al2O3 support and Pd complex are significantly pH-dependent, leading to different kind of interactions in the interface and resulting in various particle sizes. Decarbonylation performances were significantly improved by promoting dispersion of catalysts prepared in basic ammonia solution. The behavior of structure sensitivity exhibited by the catalytic performances, which are greatly influenced by metallic particle size is an important issue in heterogeneous catalysis. [48–50] Thus, the surface properties of catalysts were explored and their relationship with the size-sensitive behavior was discussed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of catalysts Typically, 0.42g palladium chloride (Sigma-Aldrich) was dissolved in the mixture of 2g 25% ammonia solution (Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) and 48g deionized water. Then 15g deionized water was added. The pH of this impregnation solution was 12. Then hydrochloric acid (Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) was used to modify the pH of the solution to 8 and 6 respectively. Pd/Al2O3 was prepared by impregnating 50g Al2O3 (Aluminum Co., Ltd, of China) particles with 20–40mesh in the different impregnation solutions for 5h and drying at 80°C for 12h. The catalysts prepared by solution with pH=12, 8, 6 are donated as PA-2, PA-3, PA-4. PA-1 was prepared in the impregnation solution that PdCl2 dissolved in ammonia solution with the pH=14. PA-5 was prepared in the impregnation solution that PdCl2 dissolved in hydrochloric acid solution with pH=1. All the Pd precursor solutions were put overnight and no precipitate was discovered. The calcined catalysts at 400°C for 2h in air are denoted as PA-X-C (X=1, 2, 3, 4, 5). The Pd loading of all the catalysts is 0.5wt%. 2.2 Activity tests The catalytic tests were performed in a 50mL stainless steel autoclave. Prior to the tests, the catalysts were reduced offline in H2 flow at 200°C for 2h. In a typical run, 1g HMF (Shanghai DEMO Medical Tech. Co., Ltd, China), 20g 1, 4-dioxane (Sinopharm Chemical Reagents) and 0.20g catalysts were introduced into the autoclave. Then, the reactor was purged with H2 for five times to replace the air in the autoclave, and then was heated to 180°C, stirred at 500rpm. Thus, the reactions were conducted under the autogenous pressure. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled down by ice-water bath. The gas was collected and analyzed off-line by two gas chromatographs (GC) (models 6890N, Agilent, USA) equipped with a FID and a TCD detector respectively. The products in the liquid phase were separated from the catalyst by filtration and were analyzed by a GC (model 6890N, Agilent; column: DB-WAXETR, 30m*0.32mm*0.5um) equipped with a FID detector. The products in the gaseous phase were neglected with a content of less than 1% as determined by the gaseous analysis. The conversion and the selectivity were determined based on the area normalization method. The contents of FOL and HMF were also tested by an internal standard, which were consistent with the results of area normalization method. 2.3 Catalyst characterization Zeta potential measurements were carried out on a Zeta Potential analyser (Malvern Nano-ZS-90) to determine the IEP of Al2O3. The Al2O3 powder was suspended in deionized water through ultrasonic vibration with a concentration of 1mg/ml. Prior to the measurement, the pH value of the suspension was adjusted using 1M HCl or 1M NaOH solution. The BET surface area (SBET), pore size (Dp) and pore volume (VP) were determined by N2 physisorption at −196°C at a micromeritics ASAP 2420 instrument. The samples were degassed under vacuum at 90°C for 1h and 300°C for 8h prior to the measurements. Palladium dispersion was measured by CO chemisorption on Auto Chem. II 2920 equipment (Micromeritics, USA) at 50°C with a pulse of 5% CO/95% He. Prior to the measurements, the samples were in situ reduced by flowing H2 at 200°C for 2h and purged by flowing He at 250°C for 30min to remove the adsorbed hydrogen. The Pd dispersion was calculated based on an adsorption stoichiometry of one CO per exposed palladium atom. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy was measured on a Thermo XPS ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with a monochro-matic Alα (1486.8eV) source. The XPS of reduced catalysts was recorded after in situ reduction by H2 at 200°C for 2h, while that of calcined catalysts was scanned as received. The binding energies were calibrated with the reference of C1s at 284.6eV. The 27Al MAS NMR experiments of the dried catalysts were conducted on a Bruker Avance III 600MHz Wide Bore spectrometer (14.2T), with the MAS spining rate at ∼13kHz. The chemical shift is referenced to Al(NO3)3 solution at 0ppm. The thermal programmed desorption of NH3 was performed on an Auto Chem. II 2920 equipment (Micromeritics, USA) with a mass spectra. In a typical run, 200mg sample was in situ reduced by H2 at 200°C for 2h, purging with He for 1h and cooling down to 100°C. Then, the sample was adsorbed with NH3 until saturation and subsequently flushed with He for 0.5h to remove the physisorbed NH3. Finally, desorption was conducted at a rate of 10°C/min from 100°C to 700°C. The Pyridine-FTIR was performed on a VERTEX70 Bruker FTIR Spectrometer. Prior to measurements, the catalysts were in situ reduced with H2 at 200°C for 2h. Then the samples were degassed in vacuum (1×10−2 MPa) at 200°C for 1h, cooled down to 30°C and exposed to the vapor of pyridine. The Pyridine-FTIR spectra were recorded at 100°C after applying vacuum for 30min. The in situ CO-FTIR was conducted on an infrared spectrometer (VEREX70, Bruker, Germany). Firstly, the catalysts were reduced by H2 (50mL/min) at 200°C for 2h, purged with He for 30min and then cooled down to 30°C. The adsorption of CO was subsequently conducted until saturation. Then the catalysts were purged with helium to remove the physisorbed CO and the CO-FTIR spectra were recorded. Thermogravimetry (TG) experiment was performed on a Mettler Toledo TGA/SDTA 851 instrument (air atmosphere with heating rate of 10°C/min). Prior to the test, the catalyst was dried in air at 100°C for 24h. TEM was conducted on a field-emission transmission electron microscopy (FETEM, JEM-2011F) operated at 200keV. The average diameter of Pd nanoparticles was determined by the following equation. d P d = Σ n i × d i 3 Σ n i × d i 2 Herein, di is the Pd particle diameter, ni is the number of Pd particles of a certain size counted from the TEM pictures. For each sample, at least 150 particles were counted. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 pH-dependent properties of Al2O3 and palladium compounds IEP is the boundary point of positively or negatively charged metallic oxide, at which the zeta potential (ζ) of solid is zero. [51] Thus, ζ study was performed to determine the IEP of Al2O3. Two messages could be delivered by the ζ characterization showed in Fig. 1 (a): (1) the IEP of Al2O3 (pH around 8); (2) the charges state of the support. As ζ measures the potential difference between the slipping plane outside the solid particles and the bulk solution, it reflects the ions state in the electrical double layer. [52] Based on the electrical double-layer theory, the negative and positive ζ reflects the domination of anions and cations on the surface of support respectively. [52] Thus, when pH>IEP, the increased negative ζ with increase of pH indicates the rising concentration of anions outside Al2O3 support, while when pH<IEP, the increased positive ζ reveals the rising concentration of cations on Al2O3 surface. Fig. 1(b) shows the pH changes of solution after impregnation in process of catalysts preparation. When beginning pH>8 (IEP of Al2O3), the pH of solution decrease after impregnating the Al2O3 support (PA-1, PA-2), indicating the adsorption or reaction of the negative OH− on Al2O3 surface. On the contrary, when initial pH<8, the pH increase after impregnation process (PA-4, PA-5), revealing the adsorption of the positive H+ on support surface. At the IEP of Al2O3 (PA-3), the pH exhibits no obvious changes in impregnation procedure, indicating nearly no charges adsorption on support surface. This is consistent with the ζ study results. Another message delivered by Fig. 1(b) is that, at the point with higher difference with the IEP, larger pH changes occurred. This means that larger amount of positive or negative charges (for example PA-5>PA-4, PA-1>PA-2) are adsorbed on Al2O3 surface. The surface electronic states of Al2O3 in Pd precursor solutions with different pH are clear now, still that of Pd complex are necessarily to be uncovered in order to shed light on the metal-support interactions in preparation process. [Pd(NH3)4]2+ nearly exclusively prevails in precursor solution with pH=14, 12 and 8, [44] while anionic species [PdCl4]2− and [PdCl3(H2O)]− are dominant in precursor solution with pH=1. With addition of HCl, the number of coordinated NH3 in Pd complex would decrease, while that of Cl− would inversely increase dependent on pH, following the equation in Scheme 3 (a). [44] The precursor solutions with pH=8 and 6 were obtained by modifying the pH using HCl based on the solution with pH=12, insoluble palladium species in these solution were examined according to the Tyndall effect. As shown in Fig. S1 in the ESI, the phenomena of the solution with pH=6, 8, 12 and 25wt% ammonia water are similar, and the Tyndall effect of all the solutions is slight, indicating that no Pd species in form of colloid exist. Thus, the insoluble Pd(NH3)2Cl2 species was not formed even in solution with pH=8 and 6. However, when we tried to modify pH of the precursor solution with HCl to 5, Pd species started to precipitate, probably becoming Pd(NH3)2Cl2 or its hydrolysed products. Thus, it is deduced that [Pd(NH3)3Cl]+ prevails in solution with pH=6. Based on the understanding of the electronic states of Al2O3 surface and Pd complex, metallic-support interactions, including electrostatic attraction, electrostatic repulsion or simple physical adsorption, are assumed as depicted in Scheme 3 (b). At pH>IEP or pH=1, electrostatic attraction interaction is expected between Pd complexes and the oppositely charged support in precursor solution, while electrostatic repulsion would occur at pH=6 and mainly physical adsorption would occur at pH=8 (the IEP of Al2O3). The electrostatic attraction could promote the metallic dispersion while the electrostatic repulsion would promote the formation of large Pd NPs. Furthermore, this picture could be enlarged at high difference between the support IEP and the precursor solution pH, because larger amount of positive or negative charges on Al2O3 surface may lead to more negative or positive effect on the metal dispersion. Moreover, higher valence of the Pd complexes could also give rise to stronger interaction. Thus, the dispersion of metallic Pd on Al2O3 is expected to follow the order: PA-1-C>PA-2-C>PA-5-C>PA-3-C>PA-4-C. 3.2 Characterizations of catalysts Table 1 presents the main physicochemical properties of the PA-X-C catalysts. The Pd loadings of the catalysts determined by ICP are in agreement with the nominal values. The catalysts prepared in the acidic precursor solutions (PA-4-C and PA-5-C) exhibit relatively lower BET surface area and larger pore diameter compared with that prepared in basic solutions (PA-1-C and PA-2-C), while PA-1-C and PA-2-C catalysts show similar BET results with Al2O3 support. This may due to the slightly corrosive effect of HCl on Al2O3 support. Similar corrosive effect of HNO3 on Al2O3 has been discovered. [30] The reducing BET surface area with the decreasing pH indicates that the corrosion becomes more serious. From CO-chemisorption results, the dispersion is roughly consistent with the expectation, except that PA-5-C failed to the assumption (PA-1-C>PA-2-C >PA-3-C>PA-5-C>PA-4-C). The representative TEM images and particle statistic results are displayed in Fig. 2 . The average diameters of Pd NPs determined by TEM are consistent with that obtained by the CO-chemisorption. The dispersion of the catalysts, except that of PA-5-C, meets the mechanism of charge interactions between the support surface and the metallic precursor during impregnation process as depicted in Scheme 3 (b). N 1s XPS spectra were examined to figure out the state of Pd species in the calcined PA-X-C catalysts as shown in Fig. S3. No obvious peak attributed to N 1s [53] can be observed in all the catalysts, indicating that the coordinated NH3 molecules in the Pd precursors (namely [Pd(NH3)4]2+ and [Pd(NH3)3Cl)] +) were removed by calcination and palladium oxide could be formed. Thus, PdO is the major species in the calcined catalysts PA-X-C (X=1, 2, 3, 4). The dried catalysts PA-X exhibit different colors, due to the different Pd precursors, while the calcined catalysts PA-X-C show the same color, indicating the same Pd species due to the color sensitive property of Pd-based catalysts. Thus, it is deduced that PdO is also the major species in PA-5-C. Fig. 3 (a) shows the deconvolution results for Pd 3d XPS spectra of the as prepared PA-X-C catalysts. Evident Pd 3d3/2 peaks at ∼342.2eV and Pd 3d5/2 peaks at ∼337.0eV are observed, which are in good agreement with the values for Pd (II) state. [54] The peak top of Pd 3d5/2 shifts to higher binding energy side by about 0.3eV (from 337.0eV for PA-1-C to 337.3eV for PA-5-C), and that of Pd 3d3/2 is increased by 0.4eV (from 342.2eV for PA-1-C to 342.6eV for PA-5-C), indicating the decreased electron density of Pd species: PA-1-C>PA-2-C>PA-3-C>PA-4-C>PA-5-C. As evidenced by the zeta potential characterization of Al2O3 and pH changes in the impregnation process shown in Fig. 1, with the decline of the impregnation pH, the anion concentration on Al2O3 surface is gradually decreased to zero and then H+ appears and its concentration is increased. The Al2O3 surface charges are expected to influence the electron density of the Pd species, for example the electron density of Pd species is increased by the anions while decreased by the H+. The Pd 3d XPS results of the as prepared PA-X-C catalysts best reflect this ionic interaction due to the same Pd species (PdO), indicating the assumption to enhance the Pd dispersion by modulating the electro interactions in the interface is reasonable. To examine the effect of the residual Cl− over catalyst surfaces on the catalytic performance, the Cl 2p XPS spectra of the reduced PA-X-C were monitored. As shown in Fig. 3(b), weak peaks attributed to Cl 2p appear at 199.1eV, [55] but no obvious differences in the peak intensity can be observed among the PA-X-C catalysts. This means that major of Cl− ions introduced in the impregnating process could be removed by the subsequent heat treatment, namely calcination and reduction procedures. As no HCl was added in the preparation solution of PA-1-C and PA-2-C, the weak peaks of Cl 2p XP spectra indicate trace residues from Palladium chloride. Thus, it is assumed that the effect of Cl− on the catalysts performances could be neglected. Based on the assumption of electron interactions as described in Scheme 3, PA-5-C, prepared according to the electrostatic attraction mechanism between Al2O3 and Pd precursors in the acidic impregnation solution, should have exhibited a good dispersion. However, both CO-chemisorption and TEM measurements (shown in Table 1) indicate that, the acidic impregnation solution leads to a poor dispersion of metallic Pd. A possible mechanism is the instability of the positively charged alumina surface in acidic solutions, caused by the attack of high content of hydrochloric acid on surface aluminium ions. [44] The BET results in Table 1 indicate the possible corrosion effect of HCl on alumina. The coordination status of Al species in the dried catalyst PA-5 could best reflect the structure damages of Al2O3 by HCl. Fig. 4 shows the 27Al MAS NMR spectra of PA-2, PA-5 and the Al2O3. The peak at 10.1ppm is typical of octahedral aluminum, and the peak at 68.4ppm is derived from tetrahedral aluminum. [43] No obvious changes in spectra of PA-2 according to Al2O3 could be observed, while a splitting peak in the pattern of PA-5 appears at −1.1ppm, indicating the formation of another kind of octahedral aluminum, which is more similar to that of Al(NO3)3 solution whose chemical shift is at 0ppm. This could be explained by that the alumina surfaces were slightly dissolved by acid in the impregnation solution, resulting in different coordinated Al atoms, for example ones partly coordinated by Cl− ions. Therefore, the 27Al MAS NMR provides a direct evidence for the corrosion effect of the acidic impregnating solution on the metal oxide support, which leads to the instability of the positively charged Al2O3 surface. The coordination status of aluminum in catalysts after heat treatment could be reflected by the Lewis acidity of the reduced PA-X-C catalysts. Fig. 5 shows the pyridine-IR and NH3-TPD of the reduced catalysts. In Fig. 5(a), the characteristic adsorption bands at 1448cm−1 (mode 19b), 1492cm−1 (mode 19a), 1615cm−1 (mode 8a), indicating the adsorption of pyridine via hydrogen bonding with hydroxyl groups on surface Al2O3 and nitrogen-lone-pair electrons donating to the coordinatively unsaturated Al3+ ions in octahedral and tetrahedral coordination, are attributed to Lewis acid sites. [56,57] The absence of the characteristic band at 1540cm−1 indicates that the Brønsted acid sites are negligible over the catalysts. The enlarging intensity of peak at 1448cm−1 from PA-1-C to PA-5-C reveals increased Lewis acid amount (unsaturated Al3+). In NH3-TPD patterns shown in Fig. 5(b), a main peak around 175°C and a shoulder around 280°C are observed for all the PA-X-C catalysts, corresponding to the weak and medium acidic sites, respectively. The weak peak around 400°C could be assigned to strong acidic sites. [58] A remarkable rise in the intensity of weak acid peak (peak at 175°C) can be observed as a result of increasing acidity of the impregnating solution (Fig. 5(b)), indicating the increased weak acid amount. However, though the total acid amount roughly follows the tendency of weak acid amount (see Table 2 ), Al2O3 support exhibits less total acid amount than PA-1-C and PA-2-C. This may because that a small quantity of NH3 or NH4 + introduced by impregnating solution was not removed by heat treament (calcination and reduction), as obviously larger peaks appear over PA-1-C and PA-2-C than that over Al2O3 around 500°C (see the inset of Fig. 5(b)), while the calcination temperature is 400°C. Considering that the added HCl in impregnation solution mainly increases the amount of weak acid sites, the NH3-TPD results are consistent with that of Pyridine-IR. As discussed in characterization of Pyridine-IR, the increased acid amount indicates more coordinatively unsaturated Al3+. This confirms the corrosive effect of HCl on Al2O3 as evidenced by the Al27 MAS NMR measurement and further reveals that the destructive effect influences the structure of the reduced catalysts. The H+ ions on Al2O3 surface are thus instable, which would decrease the assumed electrostatic attraction effect (as described in Scheme 3). DFT calculation also revealed that heat treatment could induce dehydration of surface hydroxyls on Al2O3, [59] on which H+ ions cling to, as a result leading to the aggregation of Pd species attracted by H+ ions. Thus, though the residual H+ ions may facilitate the dispersion of Pd species in the impregnation procedure through electrostatic attraction, the following heat treatment would lead to serious aggregation of particles. As a result, PA-5-C exhibits a poor dispersion, even worse than PA-3-C, inconsistent with the ideal assumption. Surface properties of catalysts are closely related with the adsorption characters of substrates, [60] which could subsequently influence the intrinsic reactivity of catalysts. In situ CO-FTIR was used to characterize the exposed faces of supported Pd NPs and their defectivity, with the spectra exhibited in Fig. S4. The spectra in the region of 1750–2200cm−1 corresponding to the chemisorbed CO are resolved and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . Generally, the peak at 2066cm−1 corresponds to linear adsorbed species of CO over Pd atoms of defective sites (or low coordination), at particle corners or edge positions. The asymmetric shape of this peak, tailing toward lower frequencies, indicates the presence of heterogeneous Pd metal sites. [61–64] While the bands around 1800–2000cm−1 (1904 and 1925cm−1 in this work) can be attributed to different types of CO species on bridged sites over well-faceted Pd NPs exposing (111) faces. [61,62] A semi-quantitative comparison of the adsorbed carbonyls was achieved by deconvolution of peaks using a Gaussian function and the proportions of linear carbonyls for the PA-X-C catalysts are also presented in Fig. 6, which follows the order: PA-1-C>PA-2-C>PA-3-C>PA-5-C>PA-4-C. Thus, it can be speculated that a high proportion of low-coordinated Pd atoms are present on PA-1-C and PA-2-C catalysts, while in PA-3-C, PA-4-C and PA-5-C majority of Pd atoms are coordinatively saturated. DFT calculation indicated that aldehyde was adsorbed on the defective Pd surfaces in form of a di-sigma complex η2(C, O), while an acyl intermediate η1(C) might be readily formed on the perfect Pd surface. [60] However, η2(C, O) is the necessary adsorption form for decarbonylation of furfural [34,65], HMF [30] or other aldehyde [66,67]. It is to say that the higher proportion of linear carbonyls indicates the more beneficial adsorption form for decarbonylation reaction. 3.3 Catalytic performance of PA-X-C catalysts Table 2 summarizes the performances of decarbonylation of HMF over the PA-X-C catalysts. 1, 4-dioxane was used as a solvent, as HMF exhibits fantastic stability in this solvent. [46,47] As a certain amount of dehydrogenation and polymerization side reactions would occur on acid sites of catalysts under N2 atmosphere, [30] H2 atmosphere was used in this system. Thus, small amounts of hydrogenation products were produced. The reaction pathway is depicted in Scheme 4 . [68] Hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis of the C6 HMF forms 2, 5-dimethylfuran and 5-methylfurfural, while the decarbonylation products include FOL and its derivatives, namely the C5 furfural and 2-methylfuran, the C4 furan. The catalysts exhibit significantly different catalytic performances. The yield of FOL, as well as that of total decarbonylation yield (Table S1) rise remarkably with increase of metallic dispersion of the catalysts shown in Table 1. Among the catalysts, PA-1-C exhibits the highest total decarbonylation yield of 88.7% (Table S1) with the FOL yield of 68.2%, while PA-4-C shows the lowest total decarbonylation yield of 5.8% (Table S1) with the FOL yield of 4.6%. The C6 hydrogenolysis products (5-methylfurfural and 2, 5-dimethylfuran) as well as the C5 2-methylfuran show generally the same trend with decarbonylation products, except that the yields over PA-3-C are lower than that over PA-5-C catalyst. It is generally considered that metal-acid bifunctional catalysts are good candidates for hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis reactions, where the acid promotes dehydration of the CH2 OH and the metal performs as the active phase to hydrogenate the intermediates. [69,70] Thus, the lower yields of hydrogenolysis products over PA-3-C probably due to its lower acidity than that of PA-5-C as determined by NH3-TPD. The FOL yield of ∼84% was obtained over PA-1-C by purging with fresh N2 in the middle of reaction to suppress the poisoning effect of CO as shown in Table 2. To further promote the FOL selectivity, water was added as a co-solvent and a yield of ∼95% was achieved. The effect mechanism of water is being explored, which may due to the hydrogen bonding interaction between water and the furan ring-branched hydroxymethyl, as well as the decreased acidity of the catalyst by water. These results demonstrate the superior ability of the electrostatic attraction interaction between the different charged Pd precursor and support for dispersing Pd NPs and for promoting the decarbonylation performance. 3.4 The structure-performance relationships Turnover frequencies (TOFs) for decarbonylation based on numbers of Pd sites (determined by CO-chemisorption) were calculated according to the report (see Table S2). [69] To obtain the intrinsic activity of catalysts, HMF conversion was kept below 30% by shortening the reaction time. Interestingly, TOFs decrease with the increasing diameter of Pd NPs (Table 1), revealing a strong structure-sensitive behavior which will be discussed below. The pH of the impregnation solution greatly modulated the charges on Al2O3 surface and that of Pd complex, causing different interfacial interactions in the preparation process, and thus changed the Pd particle size and surface properties, leading to different catalytic performance. With decreasing pH of the impregnation solution from 14 to 6, the metallic dispersion decreases (Fig. 7 (a)), because the interfacial interaction changes from electrostatic attraction (at pH=14, 12) to simple physical adsorption (at pH around 8) and then to electrostatic repulsion (at pH=6) as depicted in Scheme 3(b). Though in impregnating solution of strong acidity, another kind of electrostatic-attractive interaction is envisaged (as shown in Scheme 3(b)), the instability of surface H+ on Al2O3 surface caused by acid (HCl) and heat treatment (calcination and reduction as discussed previously) lead to a low dispersion of PA-5-C (Fig. 7 (a)). The particle size shows the adverse tendency upon changing pH. The TOFs calculated based on total decarbonylation yield decline sharply with increasing average Pd NP size (Fig. 7 (b)), exhibiting high particle size-dependence. Decarbonylation of furfural has also been found to be enhanced over smaller Pt NPs. [25] In Fig. 7(c), TOFs are drawn as a function of the proportion of linear carbonyls and a perfect positive correlation is obtained. Furthermore, the proportion of linear carbonyls reduces over larger Pd particles. As discussed in the characterization of CO-FTIR, the increasing proportion of linear carbonyls indicates preferable aldehyde adsorption form of η2(C, O), which is the necessary adsorption mode for decarbonylation. Thus, we can see that, smaller Pd particles expose more defective Pd surface, leading to more aldehyde (HMF) adsorption in form of η2(C, O), which leads to decarbonylation, while larger Pd NPs expose more well faceted Pd surface, which is in favor of η1(C) adsorption mode, inhibiting decarbonylation reaction. For decarbonylation reaction, metal centers were reported to be the active sites on both homogeneous [66,71–73] and heterogeneous [34,74–76] catalysts. The adsorbed aldehydes went through three elementary steps sequentially: dehydrogenation, decarbonylation and hydrogenation reactions. We have found that furfural transferred from the acidic Al2O3 support to Pd particles before decarbonylation reaction. Furfural adsorbed on Al2O3 by means of electron donation from lone pair of the aldehydic O atom to the coordinatively unsaturated Al (the Lewis acid sites). [30] Thus, the increased acidity (Lewis acid in case of Al2O3) may promote the adsorption of aldehyde and then facilitate the decarbonylation reaction. However, though the acidity increased from PA-1-C to PA-5-C, the decarbonylation reactivity decreased, in confromity with the increased metal particle size. This indicates that the main factor influences decarbonylation performances is the metal particle size. The catalyst acidity influenced the hydrogenolysis side reaction in a metal-acid synergistic mode as disscussed in section 3.3. 3.5 Catalyst stability The reusability of PA-1-C catalyst for HMF decarbonylation to FOL was examined at severe conditions (180°C, 16h). Gradually decrease of HMF conversion and FOL yield was observed after running for three times (Fig. 8 (a)), indicating that the catalyst deactivated after reaction for a long tiome. Meanwhile, the FOL selectivity was increased on used PA-1-C catalyst, which may results from the decreased acidity of the catalyst as we reported previously. [30] This indicates that deposition of carbonaceous species may occurred, covering the acidic sites. Thermo-gravity (TG) experiment of the used PA-1-C catalyst was performed to examine the deposition of carbonaceous species (Fig. 8(b)). Dramatic weight loss of used PA-1-C catalyst was observed, indicating that the carbonaceous species can strongly adsorb on the catalyst, hindering the activity [77] and increase the FOL selectivity. Pd particle size distribution revealed that Pd particles were somewhat grown after 5 runs (Fig. S5). Besides, the recovery processes (e.g., washing) would inevitably cause weight loss and oxidation of catalyst. The results suggested that deactivation of PA-1-C was mainly resulted from deposition of carbonaceous species and Pd particle growth. [78,79] The weight loss and slight oxidation of catalyst may also cause the loss of reactivity to some extent. 4 Conclusions The surface charges of Al2O3 support and Pd complex are highly pH dependent, so electrostatic attraction interaction in the interface could be achieved at appropriate pH, realizing the design of small metallic NPs. Based on theory, both the ammonia solution with high pH and diluted HCl solution with low pH could facilitate the desired electrostatic attraction interaction. However, the HCl could attack the Al2O3 and make the H+ ions on Al2O3 surface instable, which destroys the interfacial interaction. Furthermore, the heat treatment in calcination and reduction procedures could also decrease the concentration of surface hydroxyls on Al2O3, resulting in instability of the surface H+ ions. Thus, only in diluted ammonia solution with a high pH, a well dispersed Pd/Al2O3 catalyst could be prepared with superior decarbonylation performance. Furthermore, a strong structure-sensitive behavior was demonstrated that the intrinsic decarbonylation activity increases with the decreasing size of Pd NPs. This phenomenon can be attributed to that smaller particles expose more coordination unsaturated Pd atoms, with a preferential aldehyde adsorption mode of η2(C, O), essential adsorption form for decarbonylation reaction, while larger Pd NPs expose more well faceted surfaces, which mainly adsorb aldehyde in form of η1(C). As the surface charges of metal-oxides are related with their IEP, while the noble metals could form different coordination status, this strategy could be used for other noble catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Decarbonylation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) provides a potential way to utilize the abundant natural hexoses derived from cellulose or hemicellulose. Herein, we propose for the first time that a Pd/Al2O3 prepared based on an electrostatic attraction strategy can efficiently convert HMF into furfuryl alcohol (FOL). Ammonia solution with high pH value could realize the electrostatic attraction assumption in the interface of support and palladium complex, while diluted hydrochloric acid with low pH value could cause the instability of H+ ions on Al2O3 surface, leading to larger Pd nanoparticles (NPs) of the catalyst and lowering the decarbonylation activity. A structure-sensitive behavior was discussed that the intrinsic activity of catalyst rised with the decreased size of Pd NPs, which could be illustrated by that the smaller particles exposed more defective Pd sites, on which the decarbonylation adsorption mode of η2(C, O) was preferred. FOL yield of 95% was obtained through modulation of reaction conditions.
coredata.dc:title: Efficient decarbonylation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural over an Pd/Al2O3 catalyst: Preparation via electrostatic attraction between Pd(II) complex and anionic Al2O3
